docs.lead_paragraph: Few children from 4 to 8 years old are strapped into booster seats in cars to help ensure their safety, researchers have found, even though motor vehicle accidents are the leading cause of death for that age group. The booster seats are intended for children 40 to 80 pounds who have outgrown car seats but, because of their height or weight, are not ready for lap and shoulder belts alone.

headline.main: Safer Travels, After the Car Seat

docs.abstract: Researchers find that few children from 4 to 8 are strapped into booster seats in cars to ensure their safety (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For all the emphasis placed on technology by the American armed forces, until recently, dressing the wounds of soldiers had advanced little in hundreds of years. ''If we were to compare dressings in the Civil War and what we had five years ago,'' said Lt. Col. Anthony Pusateri, a physician with the Army Institute of Surgical Research, ''it really was just about the same.''

headline.main: Pushing to Build a Better Bandage

docs.abstract: New wound dressings and bandages can save thousands of soldiers who until now would have bled to death in field awaiting treatment, and they could also save lives of civilian trauma victims; Oregon Medical Laser Center has developed hemostatic bandage that is made from shrimp cells; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For all the emphasis placed on technology by the American armed forces, until recently, dressing the wounds of soldiers had advanced little in hundreds of years.    ''If we were to compare dressings in the Civil War and what we had five years ago,''...

docs.lead_paragraph: Carbohydrates have been taking a beating lately, blamed for the growing obesity epidemic, a raised risk of heart disease and diabetes, among others. To be sure, the carbs that predominate in the American diet -- sugars and refined starches -- deserve much of this unsavory reputation. Consumed to excess as they are now, refined starches act like sugars. Each is widely considered a major culprit in making people overweight, and being excessively overweight adversely affects blood lipids and blood sugar, fostering heart disease and diabetes.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on importance of whole grains in diet; notes whole grains, a wholesome kind of carbohydrate, contains health-enhancing bran (the outer layer) and germ (the internal embryo) naturally found in all grains; says that when grains are refined to make white flour and white rice, bran and germ and all their healthful nutrients, antioxidents and other disease-fighting plant chemicals are systematically removed; surgeon general's goal is for all Americans to consume at least three servings a day of whole grains, but nation's daily average is now only aobut half a serving; charts show recommended daily fiber intake, grams of fiber in bread, grams of fiber in whole grains and grams of fiber in cereals and pastas; photos show good sources of whole grains (L)
docs.snippet: Carbohydrates have been taking a beating lately, blamed for the growing obesity epidemic, a raised risk of heart disease and diabetes, among others. To be sure, the carbs that predominate in the American diet -- sugars and refined starches -- deserve...

docs.lead_paragraph: People with diabetes who take daily vitamin and mineral supplements may be less susceptible to infections like colds and the absenteeism they cause, researchers reported yesterday Still, the report, in Annals of Internal Medicine, seems unlikely to resolve whether the 40 percent of Americans who take vitamins and minerals are doing themselves any good. An accompanying editorial noted the small size of the study sample, and both the report and an accompanying editorial said broader study was needed.

headline.main: The Pill Drill: Does It Work?

docs.abstract: Researchers report that people with diabetes who take daily vitamin and mineral supplements may be less susceptible to infections like colds; but report seems unlikely to resolve whether 40 percent of Americans who take vitamins and minerals are doing themselves any good (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The University of California at Los Angeles is investigating whether two of its researchers aided experiments in China in which H.I.V. patients were deliberately injected with malaria in an effort to kill the AIDS virus. The China research was done from 1993 to 1996 at the request of Dr. Henry J. Heimlich, now 83, the inventor of the Heimlich maneuver, which can save people who are choking.

headline.main: Malarial Treatment for Chinese AIDS Patients Prompts Inquiry in U.S.

docs.abstract: University of California at Los Angeles is investigating whether two of its researchers aided experiments in China in which HIV patients were deliberately injected with malaria in effort to kill AIDS virus; China research was done from 1993 to 1996 at request of Dr Henry J Heimlich, now 83, inventor of Heimlich maneuver, which can save people who are choking; Heimlich argues that inducing high malarial fevers can stimulate immune system to fight AIDS and cancer; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: My patient was ready to leave the hospital before I had even met him. ''He's threatening to sign out,'' a bedraggled resident told me on morning rounds. He had been admitted the night before complaining of chest pain. Blood tests showed that he had suffered a small heart attack. His chart showed that he recently had undergone angioplasty, the process that opens heart arteries with tiny balloons and coils of wire called stents. And, the chart said, he was due for another one soon.

headline.main: The Right to Make a Bad Decision

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar comments on quandary facing doctors in dealing with patients who do not want to follow course of action recommended by doctor, especially when there are life-threatening circumstances involved (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Siblings of people with heart disease are known to be at higher risk for heart attacks, but routine medical examinations, even if they include stress tests, do not always detect problems. A recent study, however, suggests that doctors treating these patients consider combining stress tests with more sophisticated tests that measure blood flow in the heart.
docs.abstract: Study finds that doctors treating siblings of people with heart disease, who are known to be at higher risk for heart attacks, should consider combining stress tests with more sophisticated tests that measure blood flow in heart (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Heavy consumption of coffee during pregnancy appears to be associated with a higher risk of stillbirth, researchers have found. The researchers, from Aarhus University in Denmark, said the caffeine in coffee was presumably responsible for the increased risk. Exactly how caffeine affects the fetus is unclear, they said, noting that the increase in stillbirths may also be partly explained by other risky behaviors.

headline.main: When Coffee Puts Fetus at Risk

docs.abstract: Researchers find that heavy consumption of coffee during pregnancy appears to be associated with higher risk of stillbirth; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some years back, I was the attending psychiatrist in the emergency room when a young woman ran in, pursued by her boyfriend. They had been arguing on the street when he became violent, and she desperately wanted protection.

headline.main: Revising the Script on Mental Illness and Violence

docs.abstract: Dr Richard A Friedman article reports on studies showing that despite public anxiety, mental illness makes only small contribution to violence; says that since psychiatric patients have much higher rates of alcohol and substance abuse than population as a whole, crucial question concerns extent that alcohol and drugs contribution to violent acts committed by patients; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Some years back, I was the attending psychiatrist in the emergency room when a young woman ran in, pursued by her boyfriend.    They had been arguing on the street when he became violent, and she desperately wanted protection.
